articles.title: Your bartender may be deceiving you with illegal bottle trick that breaks federal law

neutral.headline: Unconventional Bartending Practices Raise Safety Concerns
neutral.body:
In recent discussions within the hospitality industry, there has been a growing concern over unconventional bartending practices that may pose potential risks to customers. One such practice that has caught the attention of experts is the act of bartenders "marrying" liquor bottles, a term used to describe the act of combining multiple bottles of alcohol into one for the purpose of efficiency and speed in serving drinks.
While this practice is not explicitly illegal in many jurisdictions, experts warn that it can compromise the quality and safety of the drinks being served. The blending of different types of alcohol can lead to unpredictable flavor profiles and potentially harmful combinations. Furthermore, the mixing of liquors could result in inaccuracies in measuring alcohol content, leading to over-pouring or underestimating the strength of a drink.
To ensure the safety of patrons, it is important for bar-goers to be aware of the warning signs of such practices and how to identify them when visiting bars. Customers are encouraged to pay attention to the bartenders' techniques and inquire about the ingredients used in their drinks if they have any concerns.
By promoting transparency and adherence to standard bartending practices, both bartenders and customers can work together to maintain a safe and enjoyable drinking environment.
